summary: This document is an email chain from July 24, 2019, regarding the medication (docusate sodium/Colace) for an inmate on Psychological Observation at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. The correspondence involves a U.S. Public Health Service Chief Pharmacist discussing the prescription status and ensuring the inmate receives the medication.

persons.name: CAPT
persons.role: U.S. Public Health Service Chief Pharmacist
persons.context: The Chief Pharmacist at MCC New York corresponding about an inmate's constipation medication (docusate sodium/Colace) prescription and its administration while the inmate is on Psychological Observation.

connections.description: CAPT states they will talk to RN about the inmate's medication, indicating a working relationship within the medical staff at MCC New York.
CAPT states they will ask MD for a new prescription if needed, indicating a working relationship within the medical staff.

events.title: Prescription filled for inmate
events.description: A 30-day supply of docusate sodium 100mg (Colace) was filled for an inmate.

events.title: Medication inquiry for inmate on Psychological Observation
events.description: Email correspondence regarding an inmate on Psychological Observation who reported not receiving his constipation medication, leading to a discussion among medical staff to ensure its administration.

locations: MCC New York, 150 Park Row, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The document is a confidential email chain dated July 24, 2019, concerning medical care at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York.
The subject is an inmate on Psychological Observation who reported not receiving his prescribed constipation medication (docusate sodium/Colace).
A U.S. Public Health Service Chief Pharmacist (CAPT) is coordinating with RN and MD to ensure the inmate receives the medication, noting a 30-day supply was filled on July 12, 2019.
The document is marked as confidential and part of the SDNY (Southern District of New York) case files, with the identifier EFTA00139772.
The correspondence highlights procedural steps within the prison medical system to address an inmate's medication needs.
